Not exactly known as a hotbed of the blue which seems such an American creation especially with his origins with African Americans in the south but due to the proximity along the border many American Blues artists that played in Canada
And a solid blue seen has developed going back to people like Ronnie fucking who organized group that would become the band and as included artist like the late Jeff Healy Tom lab and and the powder blues band and a critic blues man
Corey Harris this week we have the latest release from an artist within over thirty year career colon James whose new album is Eighteen studio record is called miles to go
Colon James ... was born in Regina, Saskatchewan at age sixteen heard the late genes cotton and Winnipeg folk festival and was smitten eventually came to perform with regional blues fans
In Nineteen eighty four when the late Stevie Ray Vaughan was book to perform in Regina the scheduled opening act was not available and call and James was invited to fill in and had only a few hours to put together it's set with the band flying colors
On was impressed and invited call him James to perform an encore with him and then to join vaughn's tour as a regular opening act including in the U.S
With the career boosts that provided common James it said that Stevie Ray going
On tour as a regular opening act including in the U.S
Was the career boost that provided come and James you just said that Stevie Ray going suggested dropping his surname on the stage name
In Nineteen eighty eight released his debut solo album which included some hit singles in Nineteen Ninety three James released common James and the little big bad which preceded some of the other records of the period that got into big band reporting like those Brian ...
In Nineteen Ninety seven James did an acoustic album called national steel and found himself on the folk festival seen for a while
But his heart was mainly in the blues and had been renewing his commitment to the blues in his recent release it
His last album blue highways issued into thousands sixteen was a collection of some of his favorite blues covers with his tasteful arrangement now he was out with miles to go which includes a song hurt James cut and played back at that folk festival when he was sixteen
And which James do including two versions on the new release
Like its predecessor miles to go features a nice balance a tight often sophisticated musicianship with classic ingredients for a good cross section of the blue styles from upbeat born Leighton dance ... tracks to classic slow blues drew a couple of acoustic tracks James is not a blues shelter
But conveyed the spirit of the blues in a more laid back style
His guitar work is also clean and articulate even when the two supposedly get down and dirty
The backing musicians are first rate and include a horn section on several tracks plus the African American gospel style vocal group the Sojourners the band in Vancouver made recording includes Jesse O'Brian and Simon Kendall on keyboards
Chris gesture in a rhythm guitar ... on harmonica steep pelletier a base in Jeff picks on drums
The record opens with one more mild that song James hurt harmonica man James cutting play at that full folk festival it's a Muddy Waters composition but James credits cotton for the arrangement
The James version features prominent harmonica Steve Mariner it's a rather typically strong type big blues arrangement with warns with a detriment
More down in the swamp musically is another Muddy Waters June ... still a fool which has the classic blues lyrics about infidelity
